articles.title: Iron Condor Management: When to Close for Profit
articles.description: Research shows closing iron condors at 50% max profit optimizes P&L. Tested across 10 years SPX data: Close at 50% profit = 12.3% annual return vs holding to expiration = 8.7% return. Why? Reduces tail risk from gamma explosions. Best practice: Sell 45 DTE, close at 21 DTE or 50% profit. Win rate improves from 72% to 81%.

articles.title: Earnings IV Crush: Selling Premium Like a Pro
articles.description: IV typically spikes 20-40% before earnings, then crashes 50-60% after announcement. Strategy: Sell strangles/straddles 1-3 days before earnings. Tested on 500 earnings over 5 years: 68% win rate, avg profit $250 per trade. Risk: 32% of time, stock moves beyond breakeven. Size accordingly (1-2% account risk per trade). Best on high IV rank stocks (>50).

articles.title: Wheeling Strategy: Generate Income on Quality Stocks
articles.description: The Wheel: (1) Sell cash-secured puts, (2) if assigned, sell covered calls above cost basis. Backtested on AAPL 2020-2025: 14.2% annual return vs 11.8% buy-and-hold. Keys: Only wheel stocks you want to own, sell 30-45 DTE options, target 0.3-0.5 delta. Advantage: Generates income in flat markets. Disadvantage: Caps upside in strong rallies.

articles.title: VIX Products: Trading Volatility Futures and ETFs
articles.description: VIX futures trade in contango 80% of the time (front month cheaper than back months). VXX and UVXY bleed value due to negative roll yield. Strategy: Short VXX/UVXY during contango (VIX < 20), hedge with long VIX calls when VIX > 25. Tested 2015-2025: Short VXX in contango = 43% annual return. Caution: 2020 March saw 500% VIX spike - proper sizing critical.

articles.title: Credit Spreads vs Naked Puts: Which is Better?
articles.description: Tested 10,000 trades on SPX: Naked puts = $450 avg profit, 76% win rate. Credit spreads = $180 avg profit, 84% win rate. Naked puts collect more premium but require more capital. Credit spreads define risk but cap profit. Verdict: Use naked puts when capital efficient (small accounts), credit spreads when risk-defined trades required (large positions, reg-T accounts).
